pitrou commented on pull request #5879: ARROW-6926: [Python] Support __sizeof__ protocol for Python objects
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#discussion_r349174006
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/array.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -751,6 +751,9 @@ cdef class Array(_PandasConvertible):
                 size += buf.size
         return size
 
+    def __sizeof__(self):
+        return object.__sizeof__(self) + self.nbytes
 
 Review comment:
   How about `super(Array, self).__sizeof__() + self.nbytes`?

pitrou commented on pull request #5879: ARROW-6926: [Python] Support __sizeof__ protocol for Python objects
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#discussion_r349759791
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -625,6 +629,12 @@ cdef class RecordBatch(_PandasConvertible):
             size += self.column(i).nbytes
         return size
 
+    def __sizeof__(self):
+        return (
+            object.__sizeof__(self) + self.nbytes +
+            sys.getsizeof(self.schema.metadata)
 
 Review comment:
   It's a bit of a fine line, but generally `__sizeof__` shouldn't include the size of objects which are reachable individually. For example:
   ```python
   >>> a = np.zeros(0)                                                                       
   >>> sys.getsizeof(a)                                                                      
   96
   >>> sys.getsizeof(a.dtype)                                                                
   96
   ```
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#discussion_r349760710

 ##########
 @@ -625,6 +629,12 @@ cdef class RecordBatch(_PandasConvertible):
             size += self.column(i).nbytes
         return size
 
+    def __sizeof__(self):
+        return (
+            object.__sizeof__(self) + self.nbytes +
+            sys.getsizeof(self.schema.metadata)
 
 Review comment:
   Ah, I had the misconception that `sys.getsizeof` would be recursive. Then we also shouldn't include the metadata size here, too.

jorisvandenbossche commented on pull request #5879: ARROW-6926: [Python] Support __sizeof__ protocol for Python objects
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#discussion_r350680568
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -625,6 +629,12 @@ cdef class RecordBatch(_PandasConvertible):
             size += self.column(i).nbytes
         return size
 
+    def __sizeof__(self):
+        return (
+            object.__sizeof__(self) + self.nbytes +
+            sys.getsizeof(self.schema.metadata)
 
 Review comment:
   > It's a bit of a fine line, but generally __sizeof__ shouldn't include the size of objects which are reachable individually
   
   You could say they same about the `buffers` then ... as those are also reachable individually (just to illustrate the thin line ;) I don't want to argue for not including those). 
   
   It's true you can access the schema / schema metadata through a python API, but whether you access this or not, the actual schema (metadata) is stored anyway in the Table (C++) object, so I don't find it necessarily clear on which side of the line it falls.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on pull request #5879: ARROW-6926: [Python] Support __sizeof__ protocol for Python objects
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#discussion_r351263238
 
 

 ##########
 File path: python/pyarrow/table.pxi
 ##########
 @@ -625,6 +629,12 @@ cdef class RecordBatch(_PandasConvertible):
             size += self.column(i).nbytes
         return size
 
+    def __sizeof__(self):
+        return (
+            object.__sizeof__(self) + self.nbytes +
+            sys.getsizeof(self.schema.metadata)
 
 Review comment:
   Yes, but the `buffers` are not really useful in isolation, while the schema can definitely be applied to multiple tables or batches (and often will). So I'd argue that not including the schema is the most useful here.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

   > What about implementing a __sizeof__ for schema that includes the metadata?
   
   That sounds fine to me. The metadata can be shared at the C++ level, but I'm not sure that's common.

jorisvandenbossche commented on issue #5879: ARROW-6926: [Python] Support __sizeof__ protocol for Python objects
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5879#issuecomment-559555597
 
 
   Added a `Schema.__sizeof__`. The problem is that if we actually want to measure the size of the metadata (which can get big), we need to inspect the dict (as a default getsizeof with dict does not measure that).
   
   Now, in principle, fields can also have metadata that is not in the schema metadata ...

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: It would be helpful if PyArrow objects implemented the `__sizeof__` protocol to give other libraries hints about how much data they have allocated.  This helps systems like Dask, which have to make judgements about whether or not something is cheap to move or taking up a large amount of space.

comments.body: Makes sense to me, should be easy-ish for us to calculate that

Someone ended up contributing these to Dask (we have a diispatch mechanism to work around these not being implemented upstream).  Obviously it would have been nicer for this code to be implemented in Arrow originally, but I thought I'd point to it here in case it's helpful to others.

https://github.com/dask/dask/blob/539d1e27a8ccce01de5f3d49f1748057c27552f2/dask/sizeof.py#L115-L145

I  started with implementing the {{nbytes}} attribute last week (ARROW-3444, which is merged now), with the idea of afterwards looking at {{sizeof}}.

Main question is if we just want to return what {{nbytes}} does (the number of bytes in the buffers), which is what the dask approximation does, or if we also want to include the size of the cython + C++ object. 

{{sys.getsizeof}} works out of the box for the cython object (but it ignores the relevant buffers):

{code}
In [38]: a = pa.array([1, 2])                                                                                                                                                                                      

In [39]: import sys                                                                                                                                                                                                

In [40]: sys.getsizeof(a)                                                                                                                                                                                          
Out[40]: 96
{code}

but when overriding {{\_\_sizeof\_\_}} in Array, I am not sure how to get to this number so I can add the nbytes of the buffers to it.

You can call {{object.\_\_sizeof\_\_}} to get the baseline, for example:

{code}
>>> v = set(range(500))                                                                                                                                           
>>> type(v).__sizeof__(v)                                                                                                                                         
32968
>>> object.__sizeof__(v)                                                                                                                                          
200
{code}

Ah, thanks. But it seems cython is adding a bit more still:

{code}
In [21]: a = pa.array([1]*10)                                                                                                                                                                                      

In [22]: sys.getsizeof(a)                                                                                                                                                                                          
Out[22]: 96

In [23]: object.__sizeof__(a)                                                                                                                                                                                      
Out[23]: 72
{code}

(not sure how much we care about those small numbers, in reality users will mainly care for big arrays where the nbytes dominates the result)
{{sys.getsizeof}} automatically adds other factors such as the GC overhead.
